poem:
**Unclaimed**

Disaster moves    
in silence—  
the stolen hum  
of a Transit's breath.

Abandoned wheels,  
no solace—  
just refusals  
from tight-lipped papers.  

I carry whispers  
of the lost—  
weekend wanderers  
refusing to stay  
where they're placed.  

In the gap,  
hope is a volunteer  
that never comes back  
for insurance.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Naivety cost me my Transit van and motorbike insurance I am a volunteer driver for various NGOs in disaster- and war-torn environments. In March 2023, my Transit van was stolen along with a number of possessions while I was working in a refugee camp. This was extremely stressful to come home to and things got worse because my insurer rejected my claim because I had been using it as a camper van at weekends. In". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
